review_title: An Embarrassingly Run, Poorly Managed Facility
pros: For the exception of a few, the employees are incredibly hard working.
cons:
To say that the Scottsville distribution facility is an unmitigated disaster, is to understate just how truly terrible this execrable place was, and is. Whether it was the managers treating associates like chattel, the unsafe work conditions, or the toxic cultural environment, there’s little that can be said to even attempt to salvage this squalid excuse for a warehouse. 
It’s utterly shameful how associates were handled, from forcing them to spray trailers with a neuro-toxin that was just handed to them without research (or the OSHA recommended PPE), to managers who routinely called them “entitled, thieving, white trash”, it was simply flabbergasting how they treated actual human beings, like soulless machines. Lunch breaks were 30 minutes in length for 12-hour shifts, and the nearest break rooms were a 10-minute walk from the heart of the facility, meaning lunches were brief, and the work tedious. 
The facility itself was disgusting. Rodents infested the dry goods area, and dust and debris littered the aisles and cartons. Every now and again a health inspector would show up, but HR would radio to the floor to stop all operations to clean, while they delayed the agent in the conference rooms with presentations. For the fall candy push (which begins in July), cooler cases are brought in from the yard, which are often filled with mice, snakes, and even racoons, before encapsulating children’s candy without sanitation.
The failure of HR to adequately staff this facility meant that team members often pulled double duty, and first and second shifts ran back to back for months on end, even going to six and seven days a week due to the inability of the Director to be clear about the dire condition of his workforce. Beyond that, the managers, who are wholly incompetent, drive to the daily quota, without actually managing things, “hit the number” is their creed, even if there aren’t the personnel to do it. 
These individuals are perhaps the worst aspect of this location, as they helm a culture where incompetence is enabled, so long as loyalty is preserved. Individuals on light duty for work related injuries are given humiliating details such as holding a stop sign in a yellow vest, to encourage EPJ drivers to slow down. 
When a female representative enters the facility, the radio will often squawk with a call for others to come and stare. One manager who was terminated for unrelated reasons, used to personally escort the medical equipment rep around, as he thought she was ‘hot’. He also took pictures of female associates when they weren’t looking, something that was widely known but never punished. They furthermore referred to their Latin American staff members as “Mexicans” or “Illegals”.
Managers not only were aware of this, they actively engaged in it. Day to day they would zip around in golf carts expressing their frustration, while failing to render assistance in fixing the identified issues. In a facility where employment was a constant problem, and where 1.75 people were fired for every 1 brought onboard, they would “point” associates for being a couple minutes late, having doctor’s appointments, or needing unpaid time off. They would also enforce production quotas that were never tested by those performing the job. The standard was off, but we fired people nonetheless for their failure to perform. 
In one particularly disheartening instance, the managers mocked an older associate who was overweight and disheveled for being ‘poor’ in private, before firing him for his failure to hit his numbers. “I’ll take him out for a beer” one ‘leader’ said, “well you’re going to have to pay after today” the other ‘leader’ replied. They then proceeded to joke about how he wouldn’t have to foot the bill at all, as no bar would allow them in with all the holes that riddled this poor man’s shirt
The team member cried when I escorted him from the building. 
The list of problems with this location are too numerous to cite, but my time there taught me more about toxic leadership than any of my 20 years prior in the same field. They are systemic from top to bottom. And whether it’s a death at the facility, a class action lawsuit, or an environmental citation for mixing chemicals in dump bins, it will one day be shuttered, for the good of the community, and for the good of any other organization that needs to know how not to be run.
